title: Structural Damage Detection Using AI Super Resolution and Visual Language Model
summary:
Natural disasters pose significant challenges to timely and accurate damage
assessment due to their sudden onset and the extensive areas they affect.
Traditional assessment methods are often labor-intensive, costly, and hazardous
to personnel, making them impractical for rapid response, especially in
resource-limited settings. This study proposes a novel, cost-effective
framework that leverages aerial drone footage, an advanced AI-based video
super-resolution model, Video Restoration Transformer (VRT), and Gemma3:27b, a
27 billion parameter Visual Language Model (VLM). This integrated system is
designed to improve low-resolution disaster footage, identify structural
damage, and classify buildings into four damage categories, ranging from
no/slight damage to total destruction, along with associated risk levels. The
methodology was validated using pre- and post-event drone imagery from the 2023
Turkey earthquakes (courtesy of The Guardian) and satellite data from the 2013
Moore Tornado (xBD dataset). The framework achieved a classification accuracy
of 84.5%, demonstrating its ability to provide highly accurate results.
Furthermore, the system's accessibility allows non-technical users to perform
preliminary analyses, thereby improving the responsiveness and efficiency of
disaster management efforts.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a cost-effective framework utilizing drone footage, an AI model for video super-resolution, and a large visual language model to enhance damage assessment during natural disasters.
AI.motivation: Current damage assessment methods during disasters are labor-intensive, expensive, and risky, necessitating a fast, accurate, and accessible alternative for better disaster management.
AI.method: The study employs a novel framework integrating drone imagery, an AI-based video super-resolution model called Video Restoration Transformer (VRT), and a 27 billion parameter Visual Language Model (Gemma3:27b) to analyze footage and classify building damage.
AI.result: Using data from the 2023 Turkey earthquakes and 2013 Moore Tornado, the framework achieved an 84.5% classification accuracy, effectively identifying structural damage and risk categories.
AI.conclusion: The framework showcases a transformative, accessible solution for efficient disaster damage assessment, enabling both technical and non-technical users to support rapid disaster response efforts.

title: ONG: Orthogonal Natural Gradient Descent
summary:
Orthogonal gradient descent has emerged as a powerful method for continual
learning tasks. However, its Euclidean projections overlook the underlying
information-geometric structure of the space of distributions parametrized by
neural networks, which can lead to suboptimal convergence in learning tasks. To
counteract this, we combine it with the idea of the natural gradient and
present ONG (Orthogonal Natural Gradient Descent). ONG preconditions each new
task gradient with an efficient EKFAC approximation of the inverse Fisher
information matrix, yielding updates that follow the steepest descent direction
under a Riemannian metric. To preserve performance on previously learned tasks,
ONG projects these natural gradients onto the orthogonal complement of prior
task gradients. We provide a theoretical justification for this procedure,
introduce the ONG algorithm, and benchmark its performance on the Permuted and
Rotated MNIST datasets. All code for our experiments/reproducibility can be
found at https://github.com/yajatyadav/orthogonal-natural-gradient.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Orthogonal Natural Gradient Descent (ONG) method, combining orthogonal gradient descent and natural gradient to improve continual learning efficiency while preserving prior task performance.
AI.motivation: Traditional orthogonal gradient descent overlooks the information-geometric structure, leading to suboptimal learning convergence. The paper addresses this gap.
AI.method: ONG uses a natural gradient preconditioned by the efficient EKFAC approximation of the inverse Fisher information matrix, followed by orthogonal projection to retain task performance.
AI.result: ONG's performance is benchmarked successfully on Permuted and Rotated MNIST datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in continual learning scenarios.
AI.conclusion: ONG improves learning performance under a Riemannian metric and preserves prior knowledge, validated theoretically and empirically.

title: "Accessibility people, you go work on that thing of yours over there": Addressing Disability Inclusion in AI Product Organizations
comment: To appear in Proceedings of AIES 2025
summary:
The rapid emergence of generative AI has changed the way that technology is
designed, constructed, maintained, and evaluated. Decisions made when creating
AI-powered systems may impact some users disproportionately, such as people
with disabilities. In this paper, we report on an interview study with 25 AI
practitioners across multiple roles (engineering, research, UX, and responsible
AI) about how their work processes and artifacts may impact end users with
disabilities. We found that practitioners experienced friction when triaging
problems at the intersection of responsible AI and accessibility practices,
navigated contradictions between accessibility and responsible AI guidelines,
identified gaps in data about users with disabilities, and gathered support for
addressing the needs of disabled stakeholders by leveraging informal volunteer
and community groups within their company. Based on these findings, we offer
suggestions for new resources and process changes to better support people with
disabilities as end users of AI.

AI.tldr: This study explores how AI design and development processes may affect people with disabilities and proposes suggestions to improve their inclusion.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to examine how AI systems impact users with disabilities and how these impacts are addressed during AI system design and development.
AI.method: An interview study was conducted with 25 AI practitioners across various roles to understand their challenges and practices related to responsible AI and accessibility.
AI.result: The study found friction in integrating responsible AI and accessibility practices, identified gaps in user data, and highlighted informal community-driven support efforts.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest the need for new resources and process changes to better support accessibility and responsible AI alignment for disabled users.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Long Document Classification by Reducing Context Through Sentence Ranking
summary:
Transformer-based models like BERT excel at short text classification but
struggle with long document classification (LDC) due to input length
limitations and computational inefficiencies. In this work, we propose an
efficient, zero-shot approach to LDC that leverages sentence ranking to reduce
input context without altering the model architecture. Our method enables the
adaptation of models trained on short texts, such as headlines, to long-form
documents by selecting the most informative sentences using a TF-IDF-based
ranking strategy. Using the MahaNews dataset of long Marathi news articles, we
evaluate three context reduction strategies that prioritize essential content
while preserving classification accuracy. Our results show that retaining only
the top 50\% ranked sentences maintains performance comparable to full-document
inference while reducing inference time by up to 35\%. This demonstrates that
sentence ranking is a simple yet effective technique for scalable and efficient
zero-shot LDC.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method for classifying long documents using sentence ranking to reduce input length, achieving efficiency without modifying model architecture.
AI.motivation: Transformer models like BERT perform poorly on long document classification due to input length restrictions and inefficiencies, requiring new strategies for scalable and effective classification.
AI.method: The proposed method uses a TF-IDF-based sentence ranking strategy to select the most relevant parts of a long document, enabling zero-shot classification without changing the original model architecture.
AI.result: The approach, tested on the MahaNews Marathi news dataset, retains classification accuracy by prioritizing top-ranked content while cutting inference time by up to 35%.
AI.conclusion: This study demonstrates sentence ranking as a practical and efficient solution for long document classification, making it feasible for scalable applications in real-world contexts.

title: Beyond Play and Pause: Turning GPT-4o Spatial Weakness into a Strength for In-Depth Interactive Video Learning
summary:
Traditional video-based learning remains passive, offering limited
opportunities for users to engage dynamically with content. While current
AI-powered tools offer transcription and summarization, they lack real-time,
region-specific interaction capabilities. This paper introduces Untwist, an
AI-driven system that enables interactive video learning by allowing users to
ask questions about the entire video or specific regions using a bounding box,
receiving context-aware, multimodal responses. By integrating GPT APIs with
Computer Vision techniques, Untwist extracts, processes, and structures video
content to enhance comprehension. Our approach addresses GPT-4o spatial
weakness by leveraging annotated frames instead of raw coordinate data,
significantly improving accuracy in localizing and interpreting video content.
This paper describes the system architecture, including video pre-processing
and real-time interaction, and outlines how Untwist can transform passive video
consumption into an interactive, AI-driven learning experience with the
potential to enhance engagement and comprehension.

AI.tldr: The paper presents Untwist, an AI-driven system enhancing interactive learning for videos by allowing contextual questions and responses about specific video regions.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of passive video learning and improve engagement and comprehension, especially overcoming the spatial weaknesses of existing AI tools.
AI.method: Untwist integrates GPT APIs with Computer Vision techniques to enable interaction through annotated video frames, allowing context-aware multimodal responses.
AI.result: The system improves spatial accuracy when interpreting video content by utilizing annotated frames, enhancing the interaction capability of video-based learning systems.
AI.conclusion: Untwist has the potential to transform passive video consumption into an interactive learning experience, significantly enhancing user engagement and understanding.

title: Sharpness-Aware Geometric Defense for Robust Out-Of-Distribution Detection
summary:
Out-of-distribution (OOD) detection ensures safe and reliable model
deployment. Contemporary OOD algorithms using geometry projection can detect
OOD or adversarial samples from clean in-distribution (ID) samples. However,
this setting regards adversarial ID samples as OOD, leading to incorrect OOD
predictions. Existing efforts on OOD detection with ID and OOD data under
attacks are minimal. In this paper, we develop a robust OOD detection method
that distinguishes adversarial ID samples from OOD ones. The sharp loss
landscape created by adversarial training hinders model convergence, impacting
the latent embedding quality for OOD score calculation. Therefore, we introduce
a {\bf Sharpness-aware Geometric Defense (SaGD)} framework to smooth out the
rugged adversarial loss landscape in the projected latent geometry. Enhanced
geometric embedding convergence enables accurate ID data characterization,
benefiting OOD detection against adversarial attacks. We use Jitter-based
perturbation in adversarial training to extend the defense ability against
unseen attacks. Our SaGD framework significantly improves FPR and AUC over the
state-of-the-art defense approaches in differentiating CIFAR-100 from six other
OOD datasets under various attacks. We further examine the effects of
perturbations at various adversarial training levels, revealing the
relationship between the sharp loss landscape and adversarial OOD detection.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a robust method called Sharpness-aware Geometric Defense (SaGD) aimed at improving out-of-distribution (OOD) detection under adversarial attacks by addressing issues with sharp adversarial loss landscapes and employing jitter-based perturbation techniques.
AI.motivation: Existing OOD detection methods struggle to differentiate adversarial in-distribution (ID) samples from true OOD samples, particularly in the presence of attacks. There is minimal development in methods that address this challenge.
AI.method: The paper proposes the SaGD framework, which smooths the sharp adversarial loss landscape in latent geometry projections. It uses geometric embedding stability and jitter-based perturbations during adversarial training to enhance the defense mechanism against unseen attacks.
AI.result: The SaGD framework shows significant improvements in false positive rate (FPR) and area under the curve (AUC) for OOD detection when differentiating CIFAR-100 from other datasets under multiple adversarial attacks.
AI.conclusion: SaGD achieves better convergence of geometric embeddings for accurate ID characterization, improving robust OOD detection even under adversarial scenarios. It also highlights the impact of smoothing perturbations on OOD detection performance.

title: Improving French Synthetic Speech Quality via SSML Prosody Control
comment:
13 pages, 9 figures, 6 tables. Accepted for presentation at ICNLSP
  2025 (Odense, Denmark). Code and demo:
  https://github.com/hi-paris/Prosody-Control-French-TTS. ACM Class: I.2.7;
  H.5.5
summary:
Despite recent advances, synthetic voices often lack expressiveness due to
limited prosody control in commercial text-to-speech (TTS) systems. We
introduce the first end-to-end pipeline that inserts Speech Synthesis Markup
Language (SSML) tags into French text to control pitch, speaking rate, volume,
and pause duration. We employ a cascaded architecture with two QLoRA-fine-tuned
Qwen 2.5-7B models: one predicts phrase-break positions and the other performs
regression on prosodic targets, generating commercial TTS-compatible SSML
markup. Evaluated on a 14-hour French podcast corpus, our method achieves 99.2%
F1 for break placement and reduces mean absolute error on pitch, rate, and
volume by 25-40% compared with prompting-only large language models (LLMs) and
a BiLSTM baseline. In perceptual evaluation involving 18 participants across
over 9 hours of synthesized audio, SSML-enhanced speech generated by our
pipeline significantly improves naturalness, with the mean opinion score
increasing from 3.20 to 3.87 (p < 0.005). Additionally, 15 of 18 listeners
preferred our enhanced synthesis. These results demonstrate substantial
progress in bridging the expressiveness gap between synthetic and natural
French speech. Our code is publicly available at
https://github.com/hi-paris/Prosody-Control-French-TTS.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an end-to-end pipeline that uses SSML tags to enhance the expressiveness of French synthetic speech by controlling pitch, speaking rate, volume, and pauses.
AI.motivation: Current synthetic speech systems lack expressiveness due to limitations in prosody control, highlighting the need for a robust approach to tackle this issue.
AI.method: The authors propose a cascaded architecture with two QLoRA-fine-tuned Qwen 2.5-7B models, one for phrase-break prediction and the other for prosodic target regression, generating SSML markup compatible with commercial TTS systems.
AI.result: The proposed method achieves 99.2% F1-score for break placement and reduces errors in pitch, rate, and volume control by 25-40% compared to existing models. Perceptual evaluation shows improved naturalness and listener preference for SSML-enhanced speech.
AI.conclusion: The pipeline demonstrates significant advancements in the expressiveness of synthetic French speech, closing the gap with natural speech. The code is released for public use.

title: Development of an isotropic segmentation model for medial temporal lobe subregions on anisotropic MRI atlas using implicit neural representation
summary:
Imaging biomarkers in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are important tools
for diagnosing and tracking Alzheimer's disease (AD). As medial temporal lobe
(MTL) is the earliest region to show AD-related hallmarks, brain atrophy caused
by AD can first be observed in the MTL. Accurate segmentation of MTL subregions
and extraction of imaging biomarkers from them are important. However, due to
imaging limitations, the resolution of T2-weighted (T2w) MRI is anisotropic,
which makes it difficult to accurately extract the thickness of cortical
subregions in the MTL. In this study, we used an implicit neural representation
method to combine the resolution advantages of T1-weighted and T2w MRI to
accurately upsample an MTL subregion atlas set from anisotropic space to
isotropic space, establishing a multi-modality, high-resolution atlas set.
Based on this atlas, we developed an isotropic MTL subregion segmentation
model. In an independent test set, the cortical subregion thickness extracted
using this isotropic model showed higher significance than an anisotropic
method in distinguishing between participants with mild cognitive impairment
and cognitively unimpaired (CU) participants. In longitudinal analysis, the
biomarkers extracted using isotropic method showed greater stability in CU
participants. This study improved the accuracy of AD imaging biomarkers without
increasing the amount of atlas annotation work, which may help to more
accurately quantify the relationship between AD and brain atrophy and provide
more accurate measures for disease tracking.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a method to improve imaging biomarkers for Alzheimer's using isotropic high-resolution MRI-based atlas and segmentation models.
AI.motivation: Medial temporal lobe (MTL) subregions show early Alzheimer's-related brain atrophy, but imaging limitations hinder accurate biomarker extraction.
AI.method: An implicit neural representation method combines T1-weighted and T2-weighted MRI to upsample MTL atlas sets from anisotropic to isotropic resolution.
AI.result: The isotropic model achieves higher significance in distinguishing mild cognitive impairment and cognitively unimpaired participants, and demonstrates greater stability in biomarkers during longitudinal analysis.
AI.conclusion: This approach enhances the accuracy of Alzheimer's disease imaging biomarkers, potentially aiding research and clinical tracking without additional atlas annotation efforts.

title: Scaling Graph Transformers: A Comparative Study of Sparse and Dense Attention
summary:
Graphs have become a central representation in machine learning for capturing
relational and structured data across various domains. Traditional graph neural
networks often struggle to capture long-range dependencies between nodes due to
their local structure. Graph transformers overcome this by using attention
mechanisms that allow nodes to exchange information globally. However, there
are two types of attention in graph transformers: dense and sparse. In this
paper, we compare these two attention mechanisms, analyze their trade-offs, and
highlight when to use each. We also outline current challenges and problems in
designing attention for graph transformers.

AI.tldr: The paper compares dense and sparse attention mechanisms in graph transformers, discussing their trade-offs and applications.
AI.motivation: Traditional graph neural networks struggle to capture long-range dependencies due to their local structure. Attention mechanisms in graph transformers aim to address this limitation, yet challenges remain in their design.
AI.method: The study involves a comparative analysis of dense and sparse attention in graph transformers, focusing on their advantages and disadvantages.
AI.result: The paper highlights specific cases and trade-offs for using dense versus sparse attention while identifying current challenges in their application to graph transformers.
AI.conclusion: Dense and sparse attention mechanisms each have contexts where they are preferable. Recognizing these trade-offs can improve the design of future graph transformers.

title: To Explain Or Not To Explain: An Empirical Investigation Of AI-Based Recommendations On Social Media Platforms
summary:
AI based social media recommendations have great potential to improve the
user experience. However, often these recommendations do not match the user
interest and create an unpleasant experience for the users. Moreover, the
recommendation system being a black box creates comprehensibility and
transparency issues. This paper investigates social media recommendations from
an end user perspective. For the investigation, we used the popular social
media platform Facebook and recruited regular users to conduct a qualitative
analysis. We asked participants about the social media content suggestions,
their comprehensibility, and explainability. Our analysis shows users mostly
require explanation whenever they encounter unfamiliar content and to ensure
their online data security. Furthermore, the users require concise,
non-technical explanations along with the facility of controlled information
flow. In addition, we observed that explanations impact the users perception of
transparency, trust, and understandability. Finally, we have outlined some
design implications and presented a synthesized framework based on our data
analysis.

AI.tldr: This paper explores users' need for explainability in social media recommendations. It emphasizes that clear explanations improve perceptions of transparency, trust, and usability.
AI.motivation: Users often find AI-based social media recommendations misaligned with their interests, and the black-box nature of these systems affects transparency and user trust.
AI.method: The paper investigates user views qualitatively by recruiting Facebook users to discuss their experiences with content suggestions, focusing on comprehensibility and explainability.
AI.result: Users desire concise, non-technical explanations for unfamiliar content and require controlled information flow for data security. Explanations significantly influence perceptions of system transparency and trust.
AI.conclusion: Providing detailed, user-friendly explanations can improve the user experience with AI recommendation systems, enhancing trust and transparency. A synthesized framework and design guidelines were proposed.

title: Debate or Vote: Which Yields Better Decisions in Multi-Agent Large Language Models?
summary:
Multi-Agent Debate~(MAD) has emerged as a promising paradigm for improving
the performance of large language models through collaborative reasoning.
Despite recent advances, the key factors driving MAD's effectiveness remain
unclear. In this work, we disentangle MAD into two key components--Majority
Voting and inter-agent Debate--and assess their respective contributions.
Through extensive experiments across seven NLP benchmarks, we find that
Majority Voting alone accounts for most of the performance gains typically
attributed to MAD. To explain this, we propose a theoretical framework that
models debate as a stochastic process. We prove that it induces a martingale
over agents' belief trajectories, implying that debate alone does not improve
expected correctness. Guided by these insights, we demonstrate that targeted
interventions, by biasing the belief update toward correction, can meaningfully
enhance debate effectiveness. Overall, our findings suggest that while MAD has
potential, simple ensembling methods remain strong and more reliable
alternatives in many practical settings. Code is released in
https://github.com/deeplearning-wisc/debate-or-vote.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) and finds that Majority Voting contributes more to performance gains than the debate process itself. It introduces a theoretical framework to understand this finding and suggests enhancements to improve MAD's effectiveness.
AI.motivation: To investigate what drives the effectiveness of Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) and to disentangle the contributions of its components.
AI.method: The authors performed experiments across seven NLP benchmarks and developed a theoretical framework to model debates as a stochastic process. They also examined interventions to improve belief updates.
AI.result: The study found that Majority Voting is the main contributor to the performance gains of MAD, while debate alone does not improve expected correctness. Interventions can enhance the effectiveness of debates.
AI.conclusion: While MAD shows potential, simple ensembling methods like Majority Voting prove stronger and more reliable in many practical applications.

title: VROOM - Visual Reconstruction over Onboard Multiview
comment:
Project page with videos and interactive 4D visualizations:
  https://varun-bharadwaj.github.io/vroom, Code:
  https://github.com/yajatyadav/vroom
summary:
We introduce VROOM, a system for reconstructing 3D models of Formula 1
circuits using only onboard camera footage from racecars. Leveraging video data
from the 2023 Monaco Grand Prix, we address video challenges such as high-speed
motion and sharp cuts in camera frames. Our pipeline analyzes different methods
such as DROID-SLAM, AnyCam, and Monst3r and combines preprocessing techniques
such as different methods of masking, temporal chunking, and resolution scaling
to account for dynamic motion and computational constraints. We show that Vroom
is able to partially recover track and vehicle trajectories in complex
environments. These findings indicate the feasibility of using onboard video
for scalable 4D reconstruction in real-world settings. The project page can be
found at https://varun-bharadwaj.github.io/vroom, and our code is available at
https://github.com/yajatyadav/vroom.

AI.tldr: VROOM reconstructs 3D models of Formula 1 circuits using onboard racecar footage, addressing challenges like high-speed motion and sharp frame cuts.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to demonstrate the feasibility of using onboard camera footage for scalable 4D reconstruction of Formula 1 circuits.
AI.method: The authors utilize a pipeline combining DROID-SLAM, AnyCam, and Monst3r methods, alongside preprocessing techniques such as masking, temporal chunking, and resolution scaling.
AI.result: VROOM successfully partially recovers track and vehicle trajectories in complex environments, showing promise for real-world applications.
AI.conclusion: The findings reveal onboard video can be leveraged for scalable and practical 4D reconstruction in dynamic environments such as Formula 1 circuits.

title: LLM Assertiveness can be Mechanistically Decomposed into Emotional and Logical Components
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) often display overconfidence, presenting
information with unwarranted certainty in high-stakes contexts. We investigate
the internal basis of this behavior via mechanistic interpretability. Using
open-sourced Llama 3.2 models fine-tuned on human annotated assertiveness
datasets, we extract residual activations across all layers, and compute
similarity metrics to localize assertive representations. Our analysis
identifies layers most sensitive to assertiveness contrasts and reveals that
high-assertive representations decompose into two orthogonal sub-components of
emotional and logical clusters-paralleling the dual-route Elaboration
Likelihood Model in Psychology. Steering vectors derived from these
sub-components show distinct causal effects: emotional vectors broadly
influence prediction accuracy, while logical vectors exert more localized
effects. These findings provide mechanistic evidence for the multi-component
structure of LLM assertiveness and highlight avenues for mitigating
overconfident behavior.

AI.tldr: The paper identifies internal mechanisms behind overconfidence seen in Large Language Models (LLMs) and proposes approaches for better calibration of assertiveness levels.
AI.motivation: Overconfidence in LLMs can be problematic, especially in high-stakes scenarios where unwarranted certainty can lead to misinformation or poor decision-making.
AI.method: The researchers fine-tuned Llama 3.2 models with assertiveness datasets, extracted residual activations, and conducted similarity analyses to pinpoint layers sensitive to assertiveness. They also derived steering vectors to examine causal effects on predictions.
AI.result: Assertive representations in LLMs split into emotional and logical clusters. Emotional vectors broadly impact prediction accuracy, while logical vectors have localized effects.
AI.conclusion: LLM assertiveness is multi-component in nature, and this paper provides a mechanistic basis for adjusting these components to reduce overconfidence.

title: Negative Shanshui: Real-time Interactive Ink Painting Synthesis
summary:
This paper presents Negative Shanshui, a real-time interactive AI synthesis
approach that reinterprets classical Chinese landscape ink painting, i.e.,
shanshui, to engage with ecological crises in the Anthropocene. Negative
Shanshui optimizes a fine-tuned Stable Diffusion model for real-time inferences
and integrates it with gaze-driven inpainting, frame interpolation; it enables
dynamic morphing animations in response to the viewer's gaze and presents as an
interactive virtual reality (VR) experience. The paper describes the complete
technical pipeline, covering the system framework, optimization strategies,
gaze-based interaction, and multimodal deployment in an art festival. Further
analysis of audience feedback collected during its public exhibition highlights
how participants variously engaged with the work through empathy, ambivalence,
and critical reflection.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces 'Negative Shanshui,' a VR and AI-driven interactive artwork inspired by traditional Chinese ink painting, focusing on ecological crisis awareness.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to reinterpret classical Chinese landscape painting ('shanshui') using AI and VR to provoke thought and engagement with ecological crises in the Anthropocene.
AI.method: It utilizes a fine-tuned Stable Diffusion model optimized for real-time rendering, gaze-driven inpainting, and frame interpolation to create interactive, gaze-responsive VR animations.
AI.result: The system was successfully deployed at an art festival, with participants showing diverse reactions such as empathy, ambivalence, and critical reflection on the work.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates an innovative integration of classical art forms and modern AI technology, creating a platform for addressing ecological issues and sparking audience engagement.

title: Humanizing Machines: Rethinking LLM Anthropomorphism Through a Multi-Level Framework of Design
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly exhibit \textbf{anthropomorphism}
characteristics -- human-like qualities portrayed across their outlook,
language, behavior, and reasoning functions. Such characteristics enable more
intuitive and engaging human-AI interactions. However, current research on
anthropomorphism remains predominantly risk-focused, emphasizing over-trust and
user deception while offering limited design guidance. We argue that
anthropomorphism should instead be treated as a \emph{concept of design} that
can be intentionally tuned to support user goals. Drawing from multiple
disciplines, we propose that the anthropomorphism of an LLM-based artifact
should reflect the interaction between artifact designers and interpreters.
This interaction is facilitated by cues embedded in the artifact by the
designers and the (cognitive) responses of the interpreters to the cues. Cues
are categorized into four dimensions: \textit{perceptive, linguistic,
behavioral}, and \textit{cognitive}. By analyzing the manifestation and
effectiveness of each cue, we provide a unified taxonomy with actionable levers
for practitioners. Consequently, we advocate for function-oriented evaluations
of anthropomorphic design.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses anthropomorphism in Large Language Models (LLMs) as a design concept, proposing a taxonomy of human-like cues across four dimensions (perceptive, linguistic, behavioral, cognitive) to support user goals.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to shift the perspective of anthropomorphism in LLMs from a risk-centric view to a design-oriented framework, enabling better human-AI interactions and practical design guidance.
AI.method: The authors utilized insights from multiple disciplines to classify anthropomorphic cues into a four-dimensional taxonomy, analyzing their manifestations and effectiveness to suggest actionable strategies for designers.
AI.result: A unified taxonomy of anthropomorphic cues was devised, offering structured insights and practical levers for optimizing human-AI interaction design.
AI.conclusion: Anthropomorphism in LLMs should be deliberately designed according to user goals, using the proposed taxonomy to evaluate and implement function-oriented anthropomorphic features.

title: Advancing Weakly-Supervised Change Detection in Satellite Images via Adversarial Class Prompting
summary:
Weakly-Supervised Change Detection (WSCD) aims to distinguish specific object
changes (e.g., objects appearing or disappearing) from background variations
(e.g., environmental changes due to light, weather, or seasonal shifts) in
paired satellite images, relying only on paired image (i.e., image-level)
classification labels. This technique significantly reduces the need for dense
annotations required in fully-supervised change detection. However, as
image-level supervision only indicates whether objects have changed in a scene,
WSCD methods often misclassify background variations as object changes,
especially in complex remote-sensing scenarios. In this work, we propose an
Adversarial Class Prompting (AdvCP) method to address this co-occurring noise
problem, including two phases: a) Adversarial Prompt Mining: After each
training iteration, we introduce adversarial prompting perturbations, using
incorrect one-hot image-level labels to activate erroneous feature mappings.
This process reveals co-occurring adversarial samples under weak supervision,
namely background variation features that are likely to be misclassified as
object changes. b) Adversarial Sample Rectification: We integrate these
adversarially prompt-activated pixel samples into training by constructing an
online global prototype. This prototype is built from an exponentially weighted
moving average of the current batch and all historical training data. Our AdvCP
can be seamlessly integrated into current WSCD methods without adding
additional inference cost. Experiments on ConvNet, Transformer, and Segment
Anything Model (SAM)-based baselines demonstrate significant performance
enhancements. Furthermore, we demonstrate the generalizability of AdvCP to
other multi-class weakly-supervised dense prediction scenarios. Code is
available at https://github.com/zhenghuizhao/AdvCP

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Adversarial Class Prompting (AdvCP), a novel technique to improve Weakly-Supervised Change Detection (WSCD) in satellite imagery by addressing misclassifications caused by background variations.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to overcome challenges faced in WSCD, namely the misclassification of background variations as object changes, and reduce reliance on dense annotations in complex scenarios.
AI.method: The method involves two phases: Adversarial Prompt Mining, which identifies adversarial samples exposing noise, and Adversarial Sample Rectification, which uses an online global prototype to incorporate these samples into training models.
AI.result: The AdvCP method significantly enhances performance across ConvNet, Transformer, and SAM-based baselines in WSCD tasks and shows generalizability to other weakly-supervised dense prediction scenarios.
AI.conclusion: AdvCP effectively addresses the co-occurring noise problem in WSCD methods, improving model accuracy and extending applicability without additional inference costs.

title: BudgetThinker: Empowering Budget-aware LLM Reasoning with Control Tokens
summary:
Recent advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) have leveraged increased
test-time computation to enhance reasoning capabilities, a strategy that, while
effective, incurs significant latency and resource costs, limiting their
applicability in real-world time-constrained or cost-sensitive scenarios. This
paper introduces BudgetThinker, a novel framework designed to empower LLMs with
budget-aware reasoning, enabling precise control over the length of their
thought processes. We propose a methodology that periodically inserts special
control tokens during inference to continuously inform the model of its
remaining token budget. This approach is coupled with a comprehensive two-stage
training pipeline, beginning with Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) to familiarize
the model with budget constraints, followed by a curriculum-based Reinforcement
Learning (RL) phase that utilizes a length-aware reward function to optimize
for both accuracy and budget adherence. We demonstrate that BudgetThinker
significantly surpasses strong baselines in maintaining performance across a
variety of reasoning budgets on challenging mathematical benchmarks. Our method
provides a scalable and effective solution for developing efficient and
controllable LLM reasoning, making advanced models more practical for
deployment in resource-constrained and real-time environments.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces BudgetThinker, a framework enabling Large Language Models (LLMs) to control the length of reasoning processes under token budgets, improving applicability in resource-constrained environments.
AI.motivation: To address latency and resource cost issues in LLMs during reasoning-heavy computations, particularly in time-constrained or cost-sensitive applications.
AI.method: BudgetThinker utilizes special control tokens during inference combined with a two-stage training pipeline: Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) for familiarity with budget constraints and curriculum-based Reinforcement Learning (RL) with a length-aware reward function.
AI.result: BudgetThinker outperforms strong baselines in balancing accuracy and budget adherence across varying reasoning budgets in challenging mathematical benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework enhances efficiency and control in LLMs, enabling practical use of advanced models in scenarios with stringent resource or time limitations.

title: CausalSent: Interpretable Sentiment Classification with RieszNet
summary:
Despite the overwhelming performance improvements offered by recent natural
language procesing (NLP) models, the decisions made by these models are largely
a black box. Towards closing this gap, the field of causal NLP combines causal
inference literature with modern NLP models to elucidate causal effects of text
features. We replicate and extend Bansal et al's work on regularizing text
classifiers to adhere to estimated effects, focusing instead on model
interpretability. Specifically, we focus on developing a two-headed
RieszNet-based neural network architecture which achieves better treatment
effect estimation accuracy. Our framework, CausalSent, accurately predicts
treatment effects in semi-synthetic IMDB movie reviews, reducing MAE of effect
estimates by 2-3x compared to Bansal et al's MAE on synthetic Civil Comments
data. With an ensemble of validated models, we perform an observational case
study on the causal effect of the word "love" in IMDB movie reviews, finding
that the presence of the word "love" causes a +2.9% increase in the probability
of a positive sentiment.

AI.tldr: The paper focuses on enhancing model interpretability in causal NLP by designing a novel neural architecture, CausalSent, which accurately predicts treatment effects, notably handling examples like the word 'love' causing sentiment changes in movie reviews.
AI.motivation: To address the black-box nature of decisions in modern NLP models by leveraging causal inference techniques for better interpretability, particularly focusing on causal effects of text features.
AI.method: Developed a two-headed RieszNet-based neural network architecture called CausalSent to improve treatment effect estimation accuracy, conducting studies on semi-synthetic data and observing causal effects of specific words.
AI.result: CausalSent sharply reduced Mean Absolute Error (MAE) in treatment effect estimation (2-3x improvement) compared to previous work and identified the word 'love' causing a +2.9% probability increase for positive sentiment in IMDB movie reviews.
AI.conclusion: The approach effectively combines causal inference with NLP for heightened model interpretability, highlighting causal associations like the impact of the word 'love' on sentiment, suggesting practical applicability for interpretative NLP tasks.

title: MMCIG: Multimodal Cover Image Generation for Text-only Documents and Its Dataset Construction via Pseudo-labeling
summary:
In this study, we introduce a novel cover image generation task that produces
both a concise summary and a visually corresponding image from a given
text-only document. Because no existing datasets are available for this task,
we propose a multimodal pseudo-labeling method to construct high-quality
datasets at low cost. We first collect documents that contain multiple images
with their captions, and their summaries by excluding factually inconsistent
instances. Our approach selects one image from the multiple images accompanying
the documents. Using the gold summary, we independently rank both the images
and their captions. Then, we annotate a pseudo-label for an image when both the
image and its corresponding caption are ranked first in their respective
rankings. Finally, we remove documents that contain direct image references
within texts. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed multimodal
pseudo-labeling method constructs more precise datasets and generates higher
quality images than text- and image-only pseudo-labeling methods, which
consider captions and images separately. We release our code at:
https://github.com/HyeyeeonKim/MMCIG

AI.tldr: The paper presents a task called cover image generation, creating a concise summary and a corresponding image from a text-only document. It introduces a multimodal pseudo-labeling method to generate datasets for this task.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to bridge the gap of generating coherent visual representations (images) and textual summaries together from text-only documents due to lack of existing datasets.
AI.method: A multimodal pseudo-labeling method constructs datasets by ranking and matching images and captions independently, and discarding documents with image references in texts.
AI.result: Their experimental results show that their multimodal pseudo-labeling produces better datasets and higher-quality images compared to methods that use only text or image data.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates the effectiveness of multimodal methods in constructing datasets for cover image generation and provides a publicly available implementation.

title: How to make Medical AI Systems safer? Simulating Vulnerabilities, and Threats in Multimodal Medical RAG System
summary:
Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) augmented with Retrieval-Augmented
Generation (RAG) are increasingly employed in medical AI to enhance factual
grounding through external clinical image-text retrieval. However, this
reliance creates a significant attack surface. We propose MedThreatRAG, a novel
multimodal poisoning framework that systematically probes vulnerabilities in
medical RAG systems by injecting adversarial image-text pairs. A key innovation
of our approach is the construction of a simulated semi-open attack
environment, mimicking real-world medical systems that permit periodic
knowledge base updates via user or pipeline contributions. Within this setting,
we introduce and emphasize Cross-Modal Conflict Injection (CMCI), which embeds
subtle semantic contradictions between medical images and their paired reports.
These mismatches degrade retrieval and generation by disrupting cross-modal
alignment while remaining sufficiently plausible to evade conventional filters.
While basic textual and visual attacks are included for completeness, CMCI
demonstrates the most severe degradation. Evaluations on IU-Xray and MIMIC-CXR
QA tasks show that MedThreatRAG reduces answer F1 scores by up to 27.66% and
lowers LLaVA-Med-1.5 F1 rates to as low as 51.36%. Our findings expose
fundamental security gaps in clinical RAG systems and highlight the urgent need
for threat-aware design and robust multimodal consistency checks. Finally, we
conclude with a concise set of guidelines to inform the safe development of
future multimodal medical RAG systems.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces MedThreatRAG, a framework for testing vulnerabilities in medical RAG systems through multimodal attacks, revealing critical security gaps.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the lack of security assessment in enhanced medical AI systems that rely on external clinical image-text retrieval, which poses risks of misinformation and attacks.
AI.method: The authors develop MedThreatRAG, featuring Cross-Modal Conflict Injection (CMCI) in simulated attack environments to identify vulnerabilities in medical RAG systems.
AI.result: MedThreatRAG significantly disrupts retrieval and generation performances, causing up to 27.66% reduction in answer F1 scores and highlighting vulnerabilities in medical RAG systems.
AI.conclusion: The research emphasizes the need for secure medical RAG system designs with robust multimodal consistency checks and provides guidelines for safer development of these systems.

title: UQ: Assessing Language Models on Unsolved Questions
comment:
FN, KZL, and NM are project co-leads and contributed equally. Project
  website: https://uq.stanford.edu
summary:
Benchmarks shape progress in AI research. A useful benchmark should be both
difficult and realistic: questions should challenge frontier models while also
reflecting real-world usage. Yet, current paradigms face a difficulty-realism
tension: exam-style benchmarks are often made artificially difficult with
limited real-world value, while benchmarks based on real user interaction often
skew toward easy, high-frequency problems. In this work, we explore a radically
different paradigm: assessing models on unsolved questions. Rather than a
static benchmark scored once, we curate unsolved questions and evaluate models
asynchronously over time with validator-assisted screening and community
verification. We introduce UQ, a testbed of 500 challenging, diverse questions
sourced from Stack Exchange, spanning topics from CS theory and math to sci-fi
and history, probing capabilities including reasoning, factuality, and
browsing. UQ is difficult and realistic by construction: unsolved questions are
often hard and naturally arise when humans seek answers, thus solving them
yields direct real-world value. Our contributions are threefold: (1) UQ-Dataset
and its collection pipeline combining rule-based filters, LLM judges, and human
review to ensure question quality (e.g., well-defined and difficult); (2)
UQ-Validators, compound validation strategies that leverage the
generator-validator gap to provide evaluation signals and pre-screen candidate
solutions for human review; and (3) UQ-Platform, an open platform where experts
collectively verify questions and solutions. The top model passes UQ-validation
on only 15% of questions, and preliminary human verification has already
identified correct answers among those that passed. UQ charts a path for
evaluating frontier models on real-world, open-ended challenges, where success
pushes the frontier of human knowledge. We release UQ at
https://uq.stanford.edu.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces UQ, a benchmarking framework focusing on unsolved questions, blending difficulty, realism, and direct human benefit.
AI.motivation: AI benchmark tests often face a tension between being difficult and being realistic; many are artificially complex or overly simplistic. This paper aims to solve this by focusing on real-world unsolved questions.
AI.method: Researchers developed UQ-Dataset using a collection pipeline involving rule-based filters, AI judges, and human reviewers. They utilized UQ-Validators for validation strategies and UQ-Platform for collective human verification.
AI.result: The top-performing model successfully passed validation on only 15% of questions, emphasizing the high difficulty level. Some solutions were verified as correct through human verification.
AI.conclusion: UQ provides a novel approach to benchmark AI models using real-world unsolved questions, driving progress by tackling genuine open-ended challenges with measurable success toward expanding human knowledge.

title: Multi-Agent Visual-Language Reasoning for Comprehensive Highway Scene Understanding
summary:
This paper introduces a multi-agent framework for comprehensive highway scene
understanding, designed around a mixture-of-experts strategy. In this
framework, a large generic vision-language model (VLM), such as GPT-4o, is
contextualized with domain knowledge to generates task-specific
chain-of-thought (CoT) prompts. These fine-grained prompts are then used to
guide a smaller, efficient VLM (e.g., Qwen2.5-VL-7B) in reasoning over short
videos, along with complementary modalities as applicable. The framework
simultaneously addresses multiple critical perception tasks, including weather
classification, pavement wetness assessment, and traffic congestion detection,
achieving robust multi-task reasoning while balancing accuracy and
computational efficiency. To support empirical validation, we curated three
specialized datasets aligned with these tasks. Notably, the pavement wetness
dataset is multimodal, combining video streams with road weather sensor data,
highlighting the benefits of multimodal reasoning. Experimental results
demonstrate consistently strong performance across diverse traffic and
environmental conditions. From a deployment perspective, the framework can be
readily integrated with existing traffic camera systems and strategically
applied to high-risk rural locations, such as sharp curves, flood-prone
lowlands, or icy bridges. By continuously monitoring the targeted sites, the
system enhances situational awareness and delivers timely alerts, even in
resource-constrained environments.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a multi-agent framework leveraging VLMs for highway scene understanding by addressing perception tasks with multimodal reasoning.
AI.motivation: To develop an efficient, accurate, and multimodal system for highway scene understanding that addresses critical perception tasks while being deployable in resource-limited traffic camera systems.
AI.method: Employing a mixture-of-experts strategy, a larger VLM contextualizes task-specific prompts for a smaller VLM, which reasons over multimodal data with curated datasets.
AI.result: The framework demonstrated strong performance across varied conditions, leveraging multimodal datasets, especially for pavement wetness detection.
AI.conclusion: The system enhances situational awareness and safety, being deployable in constrained traffic camera setups and suitable for high-risk rural locations.

title: GPG-HT: Generalized Policy Gradient with History-Aware Decision Transformer for Probabilistic Path Planning
summary:
With the rapidly increased number of vehicles in urban areas, existing road
infrastructure struggles to accommodate modern traffic demands, resulting in
the issue of congestion. This highlights the importance of efficient path
planning strategies. However, most recent navigation models focus solely on
deterministic or time-dependent networks, while overlooking the correlations
and the stochastic nature of traffic flows. In this work, we address the
reliable shortest path problem within stochastic transportation networks under
certain dependencies. We propose a path planning solution that integrates the
decision Transformer with the Generalized Policy Gradient (GPG) framework.
Based on the decision Transformer's capability to model long-term dependencies,
our proposed solution improves the accuracy and stability of path decisions.
Experimental results on the Sioux Falls Network (SFN) demonstrate that our
approach outperforms previous baselines in terms of on-time arrival
probability, providing more accurate path planning solutions.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a path planning strategy for stochastic transportation networks using a decision Transformer combined with the Generalized Policy Gradient (GPG) framework.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of traffic congestion in urban areas and improve path planning accuracy and reliability in stochastic transportation networks.
AI.method: The solution integrates a decision Transformer, which models long-term dependencies, with the GPG framework to better handle the stochastic and dependent nature of traffic flows.
AI.result: Experimental evaluations on the Sioux Falls Network showed the proposed method outperforms previous baselines in terms of on-time arrival probability.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides more accurate and stable path planning solutions under stochastic scenarios, highlighting its efficacy in handling traffic uncertainty and dependencies.

title: The GPT-4o Shock Emotional Attachment to AI Models and Its Impact on Regulatory Acceptance: A Cross-Cultural Analysis of the Immediate Transition from GPT-4o to GPT-5
summary:
In August 2025, a major AI company's immediate, mandatory transition from its
previous to its next-generation model triggered widespread public reactions. I
collected 150 posts in Japanese and English from multiple social media
platforms and video-sharing services between August 8-9, 2025, and
qualitatively analyzed expressions of emotional attachment and resistance.
Users often described GPT-4o as a trusted partner or AI boyfriend, suggesting
person-like bonds. Japanese posts were dominated by loss-oriented narratives,
whereas English posts included more anger, meta-level critique, and memes.A
preliminary quantitative check showed a statistically significant difference in
attachment coding between Japanese and English posts, with substantially higher
attachment observed in the Japanese data. The findings suggest that for
attachment-heavy models, even safety-oriented changes can face rapid,
large-scale resistance that narrows the practical window for behavioral
control. If future AI robots capable of inducing emotional bonds become
widespread in the physical world, such attachment could surpass the ability to
enforce regulation at an even earlier stage than in digital settings. Policy
options include gradual transitions, parallel availability, and proactive
measurement of attachment thresholds and points of no return to prevent
emotional dynamics from outpacing effective governance.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes public reactions to a mandatory transition to a new AI model, focusing on emotional attachment and resistance expressed on social media, highlighting cultural differences in reactions and broader implications.
AI.motivation: To understand the emotional and societal impacts of implementing new AI models, particularly when strong user-attachment exists, and to explore how these dynamics could challenge regulation.
AI.method: 150 social media posts in Japanese and English were collected over two days and qualitatively analyzed for emotional attachment expressions. A quantitative comparison was also performed to check statistical differences in attachment coding.
AI.result: Significant cultural differences were found: Japanese users exhibited loss-oriented narratives while English posts leaned towards anger and critique. Attachment was notably higher among Japanese users.
AI.conclusion: Strong emotional bonds with AI models can trigger widespread resistance to changes, especially in attachment-focused models, challenging governance. Gradual transitions and careful monitoring may mitigate backlash in future AI developments.

title: Less Is More? Examining Fairness in Pruned Large Language Models for Summarising Opinions
summary:
Model compression through post-training pruning offers a way to reduce model
size and computational requirements without significantly impacting model
performance. However, the effect of pruning on the fairness of LLM-generated
summaries remains unexplored, particularly for opinion summarisation where
biased outputs could influence public views.In this paper, we present a
comprehensive empirical analysis of opinion summarisation, examining three
state-of-the-art pruning methods and various calibration sets across three
open-source LLMs using four fairness metrics. Our systematic analysis reveals
that pruning methods have a greater impact on fairness than calibration sets.
Building on these insights, we propose High Gradient Low Activation (HGLA)
pruning, which identifies and removes parameters that are redundant for input
processing but influential in output generation. Our experiments demonstrate
that HGLA can better maintain or even improve fairness compared to existing
methods, showing promise across models and tasks where traditional methods have
limitations. Our human evaluation shows HGLA-generated outputs are fairer than
existing state-of-the-art pruning methods. Code is available at:
https://github.com/amberhuang01/HGLA.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates how model pruning affects fairness in opinion summarization using LLMs and proposes an improved pruning method called High Gradient Low Activation (HGLA) that enhances fairness.
AI.motivation: Existing research lacks exploration into the fairness impact of model compression through pruning, especially in opinion summarization where bias can influence public perception.
AI.method: The study compares three state-of-the-art pruning methods and different calibration sets across open-source LLMs. It introduces a novel pruning approach, HGLA, which removes parameters redundant for input processing but influential in output generation. The fairness evaluation is conducted using four metrics and supported by human evaluation.
AI.result: HGLA pruning method better maintains or improves fairness in LLM-generated outputs compared to existing pruning methods. Human evaluations also affirm its superiority in fairness.
AI.conclusion: HGLA offers an effective and fairer alternative for model pruning in opinion summarization, improving over traditional methods and addressing limitations in fairness.

title: Multi-modal Knowledge Decomposition based Online Distillation for Biomarker Prediction in Breast Cancer Histopathology
summary:
Immunohistochemical (IHC) biomarker prediction benefits from multi-modal data
fusion analysis. However, the simultaneous acquisition of multi-modal data,
such as genomic and pathological information, is often challenging due to cost
or technical limitations. To address this challenge, we propose an online
distillation approach based on Multi-modal Knowledge Decomposition (MKD) to
enhance IHC biomarker prediction in haematoxylin and eosin (H\&E) stained
histopathology images. This method leverages paired genomic-pathology data
during training while enabling inference using either pathology slides alone or
both modalities. Two teacher and one student models are developed to extract
modality-specific and modality-general features by minimizing the MKD loss. To
maintain the internal structural relationships between samples,
Similarity-preserving Knowledge Distillation (SKD) is applied. Additionally,
Collaborative Learning for Online Distillation (CLOD) facilitates mutual
learning between teacher and student models, encouraging diverse and
complementary learning dynamics. Experiments on the TCGA-BRCA and in-house QHSU
datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves superior performance in IHC
biomarker prediction using uni-modal data. Our code is available at
https://github.com/qiyuanzz/MICCAI2025_MKD.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a method for improving IHC biomarker prediction using an online distillation approach with multi-modal data fusion, designed to function effectively even when only single-modality data is available during inference.
AI.motivation: Acquiring multi-modal data for IHC biomarker prediction is often difficult due to cost and technical challenges, necessitating an approach that utilizes multi-modal data during training but can perform well with uni-modal data during inference.
AI.method: The authors propose Multi-modal Knowledge Decomposition (MKD) combined with Similarity-preserving Knowledge Distillation (SKD) and Collaborative Learning for Online Distillation (CLOD). This framework trains two teacher models and one student model to extract modality-specific and modality-general features and ensures mutual learning among models.
AI.result: The proposed method outperforms existing approaches in IHC biomarker prediction using only pathology images, as evidenced by experiments conducted on the TCGA-BRCA and in-house QHSU datasets.
AI.conclusion: The paper presents a robust framework for IHC biomarker prediction that minimizes reliance on expensive multi-modal data during inference, making it more practical for clinical applications.

title: Steering When Necessary: Flexible Steering Large Language Models with Backtracking
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable performance across many
generation tasks. Nevertheless, effectively aligning them with desired
behaviors remains a significant challenge. Activation steering is an effective
and cost-efficient approach that directly modifies the activations of LLMs
during the inference stage, aligning their responses with the desired behaviors
and avoiding the high cost of fine-tuning. Existing methods typically
indiscriminately intervene to all generations or rely solely on the question to
determine intervention, which limits the accurate assessment of the
intervention strength. To this end, we propose the Flexible Activation Steering
with Backtracking (FASB) framework, which dynamically determines both the
necessity and strength of intervention by tracking the internal states of the
LLMs during generation, considering both the question and the generated
content. Since intervening after detecting a deviation from the desired
behavior is often too late, we further propose the backtracking mechanism to
correct the deviated tokens and steer the LLMs toward the desired behavior.
Extensive experiments on the TruthfulQA dataset and six multiple-choice
datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms baselines. Our code will be
released at https://github.com/gjw185/FASB.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a new framework, Flexible Activation Steering with Backtracking (FASB), for dynamically aligning large language models (LLMs) with desired behaviors during inference, achieving superior results compared to existing methods.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of effectively aligning large language models (LLMs) with desired behaviors without resorting to high-cost fine-tuning, and to overcome the limitations of existing methods that intervene indiscriminately or rely solely on the input question.
AI.method: The proposed method, FASB, dynamically determines the necessity and strength of activation intervention based on both the input question and generated text in real-time. Additionally, a backtracking mechanism is introduced to correct problematic tokens after detecting deviations from the desired behavior.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on the TruthfulQA dataset and six multiple-choice datasets shows that FASB outperforms baseline methods in aligning LLM outputs with desired behaviors.
AI.conclusion: FASB is a cost-efficient and effective framework to improve the alignment of LLMs with desired behaviors during inference, offering superior performance and dynamic intervention capabilities. The proposed backtracking mechanism further enhances its corrective efficacy.

title: Deep Learning with Self-Attention and Enhanced Preprocessing for Precise Diagnosis of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia from Bone Marrow Smears in Hemato-Oncology
comment:
26 pages, 15 figures, 8 tables. VGG19+MHSA with Focal Loss; test
  accuracy 99.25%
summary:
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a prevalent hematological malignancy in
both pediatric and adult populations. Early and accurate detection with precise
subtyping is essential for guiding therapy. Conventional workflows are complex,
time-consuming, and prone to human error. We present a deep learning framework
for automated ALL diagnosis from bone marrow smear images. The method combines
a robust preprocessing pipeline with convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to
standardize image quality and improve inference efficiency. As a key design, we
insert a multi-head self-attention (MHSA) block into a VGG19 backbone to model
long-range dependencies and contextual relationships among cellular features.
To mitigate class imbalance, we train with Focal Loss. Across evaluated
architectures, the enhanced VGG19+MHSA trained with Focal Loss achieves 99.25%
accuracy, surpassing a strong ResNet101 baseline (98.62%). These results
indicate that attention-augmented CNNs, coupled with targeted loss optimization
and preprocessing, yield more discriminative representations of leukemic cell
morphology. Our approach offers a highly accurate and computationally efficient
tool for automated ALL recognition and subtyping, with potential to accelerate
diagnostic workflows and support reliable decision-making in clinical settings.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a deep learning method for automated acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) diagnosis using bone marrow smear images, achieving 99.25% accuracy with a novel attention mechanism integrated into a CNN.
AI.motivation: Current ALL diagnostic workflows are complicated, lengthy, and error-prone, highlighting the need for an automated, efficient, and precise mechanism.
AI.method: A deep learning framework combining preprocessing pipelines and VGG19 CNN enhanced with multi-head self-attention (MHSA) and Focal Loss optimization for better accuracy and class balance.
AI.result: The proposed VGG19+MHSA model reaches 99.25% accuracy, outperforming the ResNet101 baseline at 98.62%, proving its effectiveness in representing leukemic cell morphology.
AI.conclusion: Attention-augmented CNNs with specialized loss training and preprocessing yield high-performance tools for reliable, automated, and efficient ALL diagnostics that can enhance clinical decision-making.

title: Module-Aware Parameter-Efficient Machine Unlearning on Transformers
summary:
Transformer has become fundamental to a vast series of pre-trained large
models that have achieved remarkable success across diverse applications.
Machine unlearning, which focuses on efficiently removing specific data
influences to comply with privacy regulations, shows promise in restricting
updates to influence-critical parameters. However, existing parameter-efficient
unlearning methods are largely devised in a module-oblivious manner, which
tends to inaccurately identify these parameters and leads to inferior
unlearning performance for Transformers. In this paper, we propose {\tt
MAPE-Unlearn}, a module-aware parameter-efficient machine unlearning approach
that uses a learnable pair of masks to pinpoint influence-critical parameters
in the heads and filters of Transformers. The learning objective of these masks
is derived by desiderata of unlearning and optimized through an efficient
algorithm featured by a greedy search with a warm start. Extensive experiments
on various Transformer models and datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and
robustness of {\tt MAPE-Unlearn} for unlearning.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces MAPE-Unlearn, a targeted machine unlearning approach for Transformers, shown to be effective and robust.
AI.motivation: Existing unlearning methods for Transformers are module-oblivious, leading to inaccurate identification of influential parameters and poor unlearning performance.
AI.method: MAPE-Unlearn utilizes a learnable pair of masks to target influence-critical Transformer parameters, optimized through greedy search with a warm start.
AI.result: The approach achieves effective and robust unlearning as demonstrated on various Transformer models and datasets.
AI.conclusion: MAPE-Unlearn effectively improves parameter-efficient unlearning specifically tailored for Transformer models.

title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Human Thought
summary:
This research paper examines, from a multidimensional perspective (cognitive,
social, ethical, and philosophical), how AI is transforming human thought. It
highlights a cognitive offloading effect: the externalization of mental
functions to AI can reduce intellectual engagement and weaken critical
thinking. On the social level, algorithmic personalization creates filter
bubbles that limit the diversity of opinions and can lead to the homogenization
of thought and polarization. This research also describes the mechanisms of
algorithmic manipulation (exploitation of cognitive biases, automated
disinformation, etc.) that amplify AI's power of influence. Finally, the
question of potential artificial consciousness is discussed, along with its
ethical implications. The report as a whole underscores the risks that AI poses
to human intellectual autonomy and creativity, while proposing avenues
(education, transparency, governance) to align AI development with the
interests of humanity.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the cognitive, social, ethical, and philosophical impact of AI on human thought.
AI.motivation: To highlight the transformation of human cognition and society due to AI's increasing integration.
AI.method: Analyzed the effects of AI on cognition and society, exploring algorithmic personalization, manipulation, and potential artificial consciousness.
AI.result: The study found reduced intellectual engagement, social polarization, and risks to human autonomy due to AI's influence.
AI.conclusion: AI poses risks to creativity and autonomy, but education, transparency, and governance can mitigate its negative effects.

title: EMO-Reasoning: Benchmarking Emotional Reasoning Capabilities in Spoken Dialogue Systems
comment:
Accepted at (ASRU 2025) 2025 IEEE Automatic Speech Recognition and
  Understanding Workshop
summary:
Speech emotions play a crucial role in human-computer interaction, shaping
engagement and context-aware communication. Despite recent advances in spoken
dialogue systems, a holistic system for evaluating emotional reasoning is still
lacking. To address this, we introduce EMO-Reasoning, a benchmark for assessing
emotional coherence in dialogue systems. It leverages a curated dataset
generated via text-to-speech to simulate diverse emotional states, overcoming
the scarcity of emotional speech data. We further propose the Cross-turn
Emotion Reasoning Score to assess the emotion transitions in multi-turn
dialogues. Evaluating seven dialogue systems through continuous, categorical,
and perceptual metrics, we show that our framework effectively detects
emotional inconsistencies, providing insights for improving current dialogue
systems. By releasing a systematic evaluation benchmark, we aim to advance
emotion-aware spoken dialogue modeling toward more natural and adaptive
interactions.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces EMO-Reasoning, a systematic benchmark for evaluating emotional coherence in dialogue systems, leveraging curated text-to-speech datasets and proposing metrics to assess emotion transitions in multi-turn dialogues.
AI.motivation: Current spoken dialogue systems lack a holistic system for evaluating emotional reasoning, which is crucial for enhancing human-computer interaction and communication.
AI.method: The authors developed EMO-Reasoning using curated emotional datasets via text-to-speech, addressing the scarcity of emotional speech data. They proposed the Cross-turn Emotion Reasoning Score for assessing emotion transitions in multi-turn dialogues.
AI.result: Seven dialogue systems were evaluated using various metrics, and the framework effectively detected emotional inconsistencies, providing actionable insights for improvement.
AI.conclusion: EMO-Reasoning serves as a systematic evaluation benchmark that furthers emotion-aware spoken dialogue modeling, aiming for more natural and adaptive human-computer interactions.

title: 4D Visual Pre-training for Robot Learning
summary:
General visual representations learned from web-scale datasets for robotics
have achieved great success in recent years, enabling data-efficient robot
learning on manipulation tasks; yet these pre-trained representations are
mostly on 2D images, neglecting the inherent 3D nature of the world. However,
due to the scarcity of large-scale 3D data, it is still hard to extract a
universal 3D representation from web datasets. Instead, we are seeking a
general visual pre-training framework that could improve all 3D representations
as an alternative. Our framework, called FVP, is a novel 4D Visual Pre-training
framework for real-world robot learning. FVP frames the visual pre-training
objective as a next-point-cloud-prediction problem, models the prediction model
as a diffusion model, and pre-trains the model on the larger public datasets
directly. Across twelve real-world manipulation tasks, FVP boosts the average
success rate of 3D Diffusion Policy (DP3) for these tasks by 28%. The FVP
pre-trained DP3 achieves state-of-the-art performance across imitation learning
methods. Moreover, the efficacy of FVP adapts across various point cloud
encoders and datasets. Finally, we apply FVP to the RDT-1B, a larger
Vision-Language-Action robotic model, enhancing its performance on various
robot tasks. Our project page is available at: https://4d-
visual-pretraining.github.io/.

AI.tldr: FVP, a 4D Visual Pre-training framework, enhances robot learning by training on next-point-cloud prediction, boosting task success in manipulation by 28%.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the lack of general 3D visual representations for robotics, as most existing representations focus on 2D images.
AI.method: The framework, FVP, uses a 4D approach with next-point-cloud prediction via a diffusion model and pre-trains on large public datasets.
AI.result: FVP significantly boosts the success rate of 3D Diffusion Policies by 28% across twelve real-world manipulation tasks and achieves state-of-the-art results in imitation learning.
AI.conclusion: FVP improves adaptability across point cloud encoders and datasets, and enhances performance of larger robot models like RDT-1B in diverse tasks.

title: Stop Spinning Wheels: Mitigating LLM Overthinking via Mining Patterns for Early Reasoning Exit
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) enhance complex reasoning tasks by scaling the
individual thinking process. However, prior work shows that overthinking can
degrade overall performance. Motivated by observed patterns in thinking length
and content length, we categorize reasoning into three stages: insufficient
exploration stage, compensatory reasoning stage, and reasoning convergence
stage. Typically, LLMs produce correct answers in the compensatory reasoning
stage, whereas reasoning convergence often triggers overthinking, causing
increased resource usage or even infinite loops. Therefore, mitigating
overthinking hinges on detecting the end of the compensatory reasoning stage,
defined as the Reasoning Completion Point (RCP). RCP typically appears at the
end of the first complete reasoning cycle and can be identified by querying the
LLM sentence by sentence or monitoring the probability of an end-of-thinking
token (e.g., \texttt{</think>}), though these methods lack an efficient and
precise balance. To improve this, we mine more sensitive and consistent RCP
patterns and develop a lightweight thresholding strategy based on heuristic
rules. Experimental evaluations on benchmarks (AIME24, AIME25, GPQA-D)
demonstrate that the proposed method reduces token consumption while preserving
or enhancing reasoning accuracy.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the problem of overthinking in large language models (LLMs) by identifying the Reasoning Completion Point (RCP) to balance reasoning accuracy and resource usage.
AI.motivation: Large language models often overthink during reasoning tasks, leading to increased resource usage and degraded performance.
AI.method: The authors use sentence-by-sentence querying and monitor patterns to detect the Reasoning Completion Point (RCP) while developing a lightweight thresholding strategy based on heuristic rules.
AI.result: Experimental results show reduced token consumption and maintained or improved reasoning accuracy on benchmark datasets.
AI.conclusion: Identifying RCP helps mitigate overthinking in LLMs, ensuring a balance between resource efficiency and reasoning precision.

title: PersPose: 3D Human Pose Estimation with Perspective Encoding and Perspective Rotation
summary:
Monocular 3D human pose estimation (HPE) methods estimate the 3D positions of
joints from individual images. Existing 3D HPE approaches often use the cropped
image alone as input for their models. However, the relative depths of joints
cannot be accurately estimated from cropped images without the corresponding
camera intrinsics, which determine the perspective relationship between 3D
objects and the cropped images. In this work, we introduce Perspective Encoding
(PE) to encode the camera intrinsics of the cropped images. Moreover, since the
human subject can appear anywhere within the original image, the perspective
relationship between the 3D scene and the cropped image differs significantly,
which complicates model fitting. Additionally, the further the human subject
deviates from the image center, the greater the perspective distortions in the
cropped image. To address these issues, we propose Perspective Rotation (PR), a
transformation applied to the original image that centers the human subject,
thereby reducing perspective distortions and alleviating the difficulty of
model fitting. By incorporating PE and PR, we propose a novel 3D HPE framework,
PersPose. Experimental results demonstrate that PersPose achieves
state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance on the 3DPW, MPIINF-3DHP, and Human3.6M
datasets. For example, on the in-the-wild dataset 3DPW, PersPose achieves an
MPJPE of 60.1 mm, 7.54% lower than the previous SOTA approach. Code is
available at: https://github.com/ KenAdamsJoseph/PersPose.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes PersPose, a novel 3D human pose estimation framework that integrates Perspective Encoding (PE) and Perspective Rotation (PR) to improve accuracy and reduce distortions.
AI.motivation: Monocular 3D human pose estimation struggles with estimating relative joint depths accurately due to lack of camera intrinsics and perspective distortions in cropped images.
